bibl.title: Letter from Lawrence Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, November 25, 1900

div1.p: Lawrence Reed writes about post news, correspondence from the United States, and his rank. He notes that Truby is to be post surgeon and believes this will be a favorable change.

div1.head: Letter from Lawrence Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, November 25, 1900
div1.p:
Your letter reached me this morning
and I am so sorry to hear that you have
been sick- I certainly hope you will be up
and out again before this reaches you

The clipping you enclosed me was
from the Sept. roster and what I referred to
was in the Octo one- I am sure it was
my length of service that caused me to drop
for as you say my “Ex.” put me where I
stood in the Sept. one- Thirty files means
a good deal but it does not worry me
much as it cant be helped. --

We are still enjoying the most
delightful weather, and really our post life
is mighty nice- The men organized a base
ball League between the four companies at
this post and have a game every Saturday
and Sunday- we always turn out and
enjoy watching what might be call good
ball- Todays game is between the best two Teams
so were are expecting a first class game.

Humber and Miss Gardina are to be married
on Dec. 14. her 23rd birthday. They will
leave the next day on a transport for the
states and will return about the middle
of Jany- Cooke leave on the same boat
on a two months leave, he expects to
spend the better part of it in New York
and in Georgetown- I hope he will not
miss you when he calls for I know
you would enjoy seeing him- He
is such a fine fellow-

Dr Walter and Miss Barling are to be married
next April- That is if unforeseen things dont
happen- Then of course it would come up
sooner.

Dr Truby who has been at Columbia
Barracks for some time has been ordered
here as Post Surgeon, relieving Dr James who
goes to Cabana. I for one must say that
we are most delighted at the change for
James is very unpopular and quite common and
not much more can be said of his wife.
That leave us free from such among the
married people and I must say they
are as nice a set as one will ever find
in any army post.

As for the unmarried ones out of 7 only
one is a well off and he at times is not
bad so all together were are most fortunate
We havent a single officer in the post who
is a hard drinker - and only two drink at
all so there is another good thing

I have practically broken off all corres-
pondence with the Georgetown people - it was
something which would have happened sooner or
latter so they of their own accord by degrees
cut it out.

Bessie most certainly proved to be
the best and dearest friend I ever had and
I must say I regret that she soon is to be
married. Belle has been faithful too but our
letters are getting further and further apart-
as for the rest they are dead

I hear from my friend Helen Young
now and then she too will be married in
the Spring-

Did you ever know Dr Kilbourne of
the Med Corps? Two of his daughters are going
to visit here this winter - they are to visit Mrs
Humber. Mrs Clarke - my capt. wife - (he's about
46 and she 27) is going to have a young girl
from Ga- Mrs Hoyt expects one from Indianapolis
and Mrs Walton expects one from New York. So things
look like at least one may come if not
more and will add to our already good times

Hoping that you are much better if not
well with dearest love for your dear self and
Blossom I am your devoted Son
